I FRS 16 – LEASES 
IFRS 16 changes the accounting requirements for leases and replaces the previous standard IAS 17 and related interpretations.
105: The main objective of IFRS 16 is to recognize all leases on the consolidated balance sheet.
106: It establishes that lessees are no longer required to classify their leases as finance leases or operating leases.
107: In the future, they will instead be required to recognize a right-of-use asset and a lease liability for all leases on the consolidated balance sheet.
108: Exceptions will only be made for short-term leases and leases of low-value assets.
109: The right-of-use asset must be amortized over the lease term and the lease liability adjusted using the effective interest method, taking into account the lease payments.
110: Lessor accounting largely corresponds to the current provisions of IAS 17.
111: In the future, lessors will continue to classify their leases as finance leases or operating leases based on the risks and rewards incidental to ownership of the leased asset.
112: The TRATON GROUP applies the modified retrospective transition method for the first-time adoption of IFRS 16.
113: As a result of the first-time recognition of the right-of-use assets and corresponding lease liabilities at the same amount the consolidated balance sheet total will increase according to the preliminary assessment by approximately 2%.
114: The increase in financial liabilities has a negative impact on the net liquidity of the TRATON GROUP.
115: No significant impact on equity is expected.
116: In contrast to the previous approach to include expenses for operating leases in the operating profit, under IFRS 16 only the amortization of the right-of-use assets is included in the operating profit.
117: Interest expenses from the compounding of the lease liability are shown in the financial result.
118: Based on the lease contracts existing as of January 1, 2019, an increase in operating profit in the low two-digit millions of euros is expected.

Noncurrent assets held for sale and discontinued operations include both individual noncurrent assets and groups of assets, together with liabilities directly associated with those assets (disposal groups), if their carrying amounts will be recovered principally through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use.
307: Noncurrent assets classified as held for sale, either individually or as part of a disposal group, are presented in separate line items in the consolidated balance sheet.
308: To the extent that they are in the measurement scope of IFRS 5 they are measured at the lower of their carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell, and are no longer depreciated or amortized.
309: If there is any subsequent increase in fair value less costs to sell, a remeasurement gain is recognized.
310: The remeasurement gain may not exceed the cumulative impairment losses already recognized for that asset.
311: A discontinued operation is a component of an entity that represents a major line of business of the TRATON GROUP and that is classified as held for sale or has been disposed of.
312: The assets and liabilities of a discontinued operation are classified as held for sale in the consolidated balance sheet until the disposal is completed, and are measured at the lower of their carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell.
313: Gains or losses recognized on measurement to fair value less costs to sell, gains or losses on the disposal, and the post-tax profit or loss of the discontinued operation are presented separately in the consolidated income statement as “Result from discontinued operations, net of tax”.
314: Prior-period amounts in the consolidated income statement are adjusted accordingly.
315: Discontinued operations are presented separately in the statement of cash flows.
316: In these cases, too, prior period amounts are adjusted accordingly.
317: The elimination of intercompany transactions between TRATON and discontinued operations is based on the post-disposal arrangement situation.
318: Where TRATON expects the arrangement to be continued post-disposal, the elimination is made against the discontinued operation.
319: Reversely, if the arrangement will not be continued post-disposal the elimination is made against the continuing operation.
320: Notes to the consolidated financial statements outside note “Noncurrent assets held for sale and discontinued operations” generally relate to continuing operations, unless explicitly stated or otherwise required by IFRSs.

REVENU E FROM CONTRACTS WITH CUSTOMERS 
Revenue is recognized once a performance obligation in a contract with a customer is satisfied.
347: Discounts, customer rebates, and other sales allowances are deducted from the transaction price.
348: If a contract contains multiple performance obligations, the transaction price is allocated to each performance obligation.
349: Variable consideration is only included in the transaction price to the extent that it is highly probable that a reversal of revenue will not occur.
350: Revenue from goods is recognized at the point in time when control over the product is transferred to the customer, which is normally the date of delivery of the vehicle.
351: Revenue from service contracts is recognized when the service has been rendered.
352: In the case of long-term contracts for services, revenue is recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the contract or, if services are not rendered on a straight-line basis, based on the stage of completion using the cost-to-cost method.

Sales revenue from financing arrangements and finance lease agreements is recognized using the effective interest method over the contract term.
359: If non-interest-bearing or low-interest vehicle financing arrangements are agreed, sales revenue is reduced by the interest benefits granted.
360: In case of operating leases and short-term rentals of vehicles, revenue is allocated on a straight-line basis over the lease or rental period.
361: Leases and rentals mainly involve new trucks and buses.
362: The asset remains on the consolidated balance sheet as a lease asset.
363: Income from sale transactions in which a Group company incurs a buyback obligation at a predetermined value is not immediately recognized in full as revenue when control does not transfer to the customer.
364: The difference between the selling price and the present value of the buyback price is recognized as revenue on a straight-line basis over the period until the return of the item sold.
365: Prior to that time, the assets are carried as lease assets on the consolidated balance sheet.

370: This item also includes the costs of additions to warranty provisions for statutory and contractual guarantee obligations which are recognized when the products are sold.

698:
Provisions for pensions and other post-employment benefits 
Provisions for pensions are recognized for commitments in the form of retirement, invalidity, dependents and other benefits payable under pension plans.
699: The benefits provided by the Group vary according to the legal, tax and economic circumstances of the country concerned, and usually depend on the length of service and remuneration of the employees.
700: TRATON GROUP companies provide occupational pensions under both defined contribution and defined benefit plans.
701: In the case of defined contribution plans, companies contribute to state or private pension schemes based on legal or contractual requirements, or on a voluntary basis.
702:
Once the contributions have been paid, there are no further obligations for the TRATON 
GROUP.
703: Current contributions are recognized as pension expenses of the period concerned.
704: They amounted to a total of €276 million as of December 31, 2018 (December 31, 2017: €257 million, December 31, 2016: €238 million) in the TRATON GROUP.
705: In the case of defined benefit plans, a distinction is made between unfunded pensions and plans funded by external assets.
706:
The pension provisions for defined benefits are measured by independent actuaries using the internationally accepted projected unit credit method in accordance with IAS 19, under which the future obligations are measured based on the ratable 

58 
 benefit entitlements earned as of the balance sheet date.
707: Measurement reflects actuarial assumptions as to discount rates, salary and pension trends, employee turnover rates, longevity and increases in healthcare costs, which were determined for each Group company depending on the economic environment.
708: Remeasurements arise from differences between what has actually occurred and the prior-year assumptions as well as from changes in assumptions.
709: They are recognized in other comprehensive income, net of deferred taxes, in the period in which they arise.
710:
Significant Pension Arrangements in the TRATON GROUP 
For the period after their active working life, the TRATON GROUP offers its employees benefits under attractive, modern occupational pension arrangements.
711:
Most of the arrangements in the TRATON GROUP classify as defined benefit plans under 
IAS 19.
712:
To reduce the risks associated with defined benefit plans, in particular longevity, salary increases and inflation, the 
TRATON GROUP makes use of defined benefit plans whose benefits are funded by appropriate external plan assets.
713: The abovementioned risks have been largely reduced in these pension plans.
714: The significant pension plans are described in the following.
715:
SCANIA’S U N FU NDED SWEDISH PE NSION PLANS 
Scania’s employees in Sweden are covered through post-employment benefit plans that offer benefits in the form of retirement pensions, early retirement pensions, dependent’s protection, health care and severance pay.
716: Depending on their function and age, employees are eligible to enroll in either the SAF/LO defined-contribution plan or the ITP plan, both of which are multi-employer plans based on collective agreements.
717: The ITP plan has two parts, ITP1, which is a defined-contribution plan applying to employees born in 1979 or later, and ITP2, a defined-benefit plan applying to employees born before 1979.
718:
Most of the ITP2 plan is funded solely through recognized provisions, safeguarded through credit insurance from the mutual insurance company Försäkringsbolaget PRI 
Pensionsgaranti, which also administers the plan.
719: Asides from these obligations, there are early retirement defined-benefit obligations for workers who at the age of 62 have worked for 30 years or who at the age of 63 have worked for 25 years in the company, as well as to a limited number of persons in managerial positions.
720: As the obligations are funded solely through recognized provisions, the company bears the risks arising from changes in the longevity of plan participants as well as from changes in interest rate risk, as the present value of the guaranteed obligation rises as interest rates fall and is therefore exposed to interest rate risk.
721:
MAN’S GERMAN PENSION PLANS FU NDED BY EXTERNAL PLAN ASSET S 
Once their active working life is over, the MAN Group grants its employees in Germany benefits provided by a modern, attractive occupational pension system that constitute a key element of its remuneration policy.
722: Occupational pensions provide reliable additional retirement benefits as well as risk protection in the event of invalidity or death.
723: Under MAN’s current pension plans, all active employees receive employer contributions that are tied to their remuneration and can also make additional provision through deferred compensation — which is employer-subsidized for staff subject to collective bargaining agreements.
724: The employer- and employee-funded contributions plus returns on capital market investments allow staff to accumulate plan assets during their active employment that are paid out as a lump sum or in installments on retirement, or that can be annuitized in certain cases.
725: The risk of the investments is gradually reduced as employees get older (lifecycle concept).
726: The performance of the plan assets is based on the return on capital investments.
727: In line with the legislative requirements, at a minimum the total amount of contributions paid in for the employee are paid out when the employee retires.
728: Former employees, pensioners, or employees with vested benefits who have left MAN have benefit commitments from discontinued pension plans, most of which are designed to provide lifelong pension payments.
729: These commitments are exposed to the standard longevity and inflation risks, which are regularly monitored and assessed.
730: MAN’s German pension assets are managed by MAN Pension Trust e.V.
732: These assets are irrevocably protected from recourse by the Group companies and may only be used to fund current pension benefit payments or to settle claims by employees in the event of insolvency.
733: Proper management and utilization of the trust assets are supervised by independent trustees.
734:
Additionally, MAN Pensionsfonds AG is regulated by the Bundesanstalt für 
Finanzdienstleistungsaufsicht (BaFin — German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority).

736: Strategic allocation of the pension assets is based on regular asset/liability management studies.
737: The assets attributable to the current pension plans are generally invested with the objective of covering the performance risk resulting from the return parameters of the lifecycle concept.

Capital management 
The Group’s capital management ensures that its goals and strategies can be achieved in the interests of shareholders, employees and other stakeholders.
963: In particular, management focuses on generating the minimum return on invested assets in the Industrial Business that is required by the capital markets, and on increasing the return on equity in Financial Services.
964: In the process, it aims overall to achieve the highest possible growth in the value of the Group and its divisions for the benefit of all the Company’s stakeholder groups.
965: In order to maximize the use of resources in the Industrial Business and to measure the success of this, we have for a number of years been using a value-based management system, with return on investment (ROI) as a relative indicator.
966: The return on investment (ROI) is defined as the return on invested capital for a particular period based on the operating profit after tax.
967: The invested capital is calculated as total operating assets reported in the balance sheet (property, plant and equipment, intangible assets (excluding goodwill), investment property, lease assets, inventories, trade receivables and certain other assets) less non-interest bearing liabilities (trade payables and advanced payments received).
968: The average invested capital is defined as the sum of invested capital at the beginning of the reporting period and the invested capital at the end of the reporting period divided by two.
969: Operating profit after tax is calculated by deducting average taxes of 30.0% from operating profit.
970: If the return on investment exceeds the market cost of capital, there is an increase in the value of the invested capital.
